Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Expectation2: Prepare sermons and deliver weekly messages during Shabbat services.
Situation2: The regular weekly Shabbat service is approaching.
Story: The shrill wail of the evacuation alarm slices through the clamor of the construction site, and I drop my tools, heart pounding. The foreman’s voice booms, “Everyone to the muster point, now!” I know the drill—no exceptions, no delays. As I fall in line with the others, sweat trickling down my back, my phone vibrates in my pocket. A reminder: Shabbat service in two hours. My congregation expects a thoughtful sermon, words of comfort and wisdom. I haven’t finished preparing; my notes are scattered, my mind still tangled in steel beams and concrete. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—my team counting on me for safety, my community counting on me for guidance. I can’t be in two places at once, can’t give my all to both. The tension coils in my chest as I shuffle forward, torn between the hard hat on my head and the yarmulke in my heart, not knowing which duty I’ll have to let down.
